001package gust.backend.runtime;
002
003import com.google.api.core.ApiFuture;
004import com.google.api.core.ApiFutureToListenableFuture;
005import com.google.common.util.concurrent.Futures;
006import com.google.common.util.concurrent.ListenableFuture;
007import com.google.common.util.concurrent.MoreExecutors;
008import com.google.common.util.concurrent.SettableFuture;
009import org.reactivestreams.Publisher;
010import org.reactivestreams.Subscriber;
011import org.reactivestreams.Subscription;
012
013import javax.annotation.Nonnull;
014import javax.annotation.Nullable;
015import javax.annotation.concurrent.Immutable;
016import javax.annotation.concurrent.ThreadSafe;
017import java.util.*;
018import java.util.concurrent.*;
019import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicBoolean;
020import java.util.function.Consumer;
021
022
023/**
024 * Adapts future/async value containers from different frameworks (namely, Reactive Java, Guava, and the JDK).
025 *
026 * <p>Create a new {@link ReactiveFuture} by using any of the {@code wrap)} factory methods. The resulting object is
027 * usable as a {@link Publisher}, {@link ListenableFuture}, or {@link ApiFuture}. This object simply wraps whatever
028 * inner object is provided, and as such instances are lightweight; there is no default functionality after immediate
029 * construction in most cases.</p>
030 *
031 * <p><b>Caveat:</b> when using a {@link Publisher} as a {@link ListenableFuture} (i.e. wrapping a {@link Publisher} and
032 * then using any of the typical future methods, like {@link ListenableFuture#addListener(Runnable, Executor)}), the
033 * underlying publisher may not publish more than one value. This is to prevent dropping intermediate values on the
034 * floor, silently, before dispatching the future's callbacks, which generally only accept one value. Other than this,
035 * things should work "as expected" whether you're looking at them from a Guava, JDK, or Reactive perspective.</p>
036 *
037 * @see Publisher Reactive Java type adapted by this object.
038 * @see ListenableFuture Guava's extension of the JDK's basic {@link Future}, which adds listener support.
039 * @see ApiFuture Lightweight Guava-like future meant to avoid dependencies on Java in API libraries.
040 * @see #wrap(Publisher) To wrap a {@link Publisher}.
041 * @see #wrap(ListenableFuture, Executor) To wrap a {@link ListenableFuture}.
042 * @see #wrap(ApiFuture, Executor) To wrap an {@link ApiFuture}.
043 */
044@Immutable
045@ThreadSafe
046@SuppressWarnings("UnstableApiUsage")
047public final class ReactiveFuture<R> implements Publisher<R>, ListenableFuture<R>, ApiFuture<R> {
048  /** Inner future, if one is set. Otherwise {@link Optional#empty()}. */
049  private final Optional<ListenableFuture<R>> future;
050
051  /** If a `publisher` is present, this object adapts it to a `future`. */
052  private final @Nullable PublisherListenableFuture<R> publisherAdapter;
053
054  /** If a `future` is present, this object adapts it to a `publisher`. */
055  private final @Nullable ListenableFuturePublisher<R> futureAdapter;
056
057  /**
058   * Spawn a reactive/future adapter in a reactive context, from a {@link Publisher}. Constructing a reactive future in
059   * this manner causes the object to operate in a "publisher-backed" mode.
060   *
061   * @param publisher Publisher to work with.
062   */
063  private ReactiveFuture(@Nonnull Publisher<R> publisher) {
064    this.future = Optional.empty();
065    this.futureAdapter = null;
066    this.publisherAdapter = new PublisherListenableFuture<>(publisher);
067  }
068
069  /**
070   * Spawn a reactive/future adapter in a future context, from a {@link ListenableFuture}. Constructing a reactive
071   * future in this manner causes the object to operate in a "future-backed" mode.
072   *
073   * @param future Future to work with.
074   * @param executor Executor to use when running callbacks.
075   */
076  private ReactiveFuture(@Nonnull ListenableFuture<R> future, @Nonnull Executor executor) {
077    this.future = Optional.of(future);
078    this.futureAdapter = new ListenableFuturePublisher<>(future, executor);
079    this.publisherAdapter = null;
080  }
081
082  /** @return Internal future representation. */
083  private @Nonnull ListenableFuture<R> resolveFuture() {
084    if (this.publisherAdapter != null)
085      return this.publisherAdapter;
086    //noinspection OptionalGetWithoutIsPresent
087    return this.future.get();
088  }
089
090  /** @return Internal publisher representation. */
091  private @Nonnull Publisher<R> resolvePublisher() {
092    if (this.futureAdapter != null)
093      return this.futureAdapter;
094    return Objects.requireNonNull(this.publisherAdapter);
095  }
096
097  // -- Public API -- //
098  /**
099   * Wrap a Reactive Java {@link Publisher} in a universal {@link ReactiveFuture}, such that it may be used with any
100   * interface requiring a supported async or future value.
101   *
102   * <p>The resulting object is usable as any of {@link ListenableFuture}, {@link Publisher}, or {@link ApiFuture}. See
103   * class docs for more information.</p>
104   *
105   * <p><b>Note:</b> to use a {@link Publisher} as a {@link Future} (or any descendent thereof), the {@link Publisher}
106   * may only emit one value, and no more. Emitting multiple items is considered an error when wrapped in this class and
107   * accessed as a {@link Future}, to prevent silently dropping intermediate values on the floor.</p>
108   *
109   * @see #wrap(ListenableFuture, Executor) Wraps a {@link ListenableFuture} from Guava.
110   * @param publisher Reactive publisher to wrap.
111   * @param <R> Return or emission type of the publisher.
112   * @return Wrapped reactive future object.
113   * @throws IllegalArgumentException If the passed `publisher` is `null`.
114   */
115  public static @Nonnull <R> ReactiveFuture<R> wrap(@Nonnull Publisher<R> publisher) {
116    //noinspection ConstantConditions
117    if (publisher == null) throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot wrap `null` publisher.");
118    return new ReactiveFuture<>(publisher);
119  }
120
121  /**
122   * Wrap a Guava {@link ListenableFuture} in a universal {@link ReactiveFuture}, such that it may be used with any
123   * interface requiring a supported async or future value.
124   *
125   * <p><b>Warning:</b> this method uses {@link MoreExecutors#directExecutor()} for callback execution. You should only
126   * do this if the callbacks associated with your future are lightweight and exit quickly. Otherwise, it is heavily
127   * recommended to use the variants of {@code wrap} that accept an {@link Executor}. For instance, the corresponding
128   * method to this one is {@link #wrap(ListenableFuture, Executor)}.</p>
129   *
130   * <p>The resulting object is usable as any of {@link ListenableFuture}, {@link Publisher}, or {@link ApiFuture}. See
131   * class docs for more information.</p>
132   *
133   * <p><b>Note:</b> to use a {@link Publisher} as a {@link Future} (or any descendent thereof), the {@link Publisher}
134   * may only emit one value, and no more. Emitting multiple items is considered an error when wrapped in this class and
135   * accessed as a {@link Future}, to prevent silently dropping intermediate values on the floor.</p>
136   *
137   * @see #wrap(Publisher) Wraps a Reactive Java {@link Publisher}.
138   * @param future Future value to wrap.
139   * @param <R> Return value type for the future.
140   * @return Wrapped reactive future object.
141   * @throws IllegalArgumentException If the passed `future` is `null`.
142   */
143  public static @Nonnull <R> ReactiveFuture<R> wrap(@Nonnull ListenableFuture<R> future) {
144    return wrap(future, MoreExecutors.directExecutor());
145  }
146
147  /**
148   * Wrap a Guava {@link ListenableFuture} in a universal {@link ReactiveFuture}, such that it may be used with any
149   * interface requiring a supported async or future value.
150   *
151   * <p>The resulting object is usable as any of {@link ListenableFuture}, {@link Publisher}, or {@link ApiFuture}. See
152   * class docs for more information.</p>
153   *
154   * <p><b>Note:</b> to use a {@link Publisher} as a {@link Future} (or any descendent thereof), the {@link Publisher}
155   * may only emit one value, and no more. Emitting multiple items is considered an error when wrapped in this class and
156   * accessed as a {@link Future}, to prevent silently dropping intermediate values on the floor.</p>
157   *
158   * @see #wrap(Publisher) Wraps a Reactive Java {@link Publisher}.
159   * @param future Future value to wrap.
160   * @param executor Executor to dispatch callbacks with.
161   * @param <R> Return value type for the future.
162   * @return Wrapped reactive future object.
163   * @throws IllegalArgumentException If the passed `future` is `null`.
164   */
165  public static @Nonnull <R> ReactiveFuture<R> wrap(@Nonnull ListenableFuture<R> future, @Nonnull Executor executor) {
166    //noinspection ConstantConditions
167    if (future == null) throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot wrap `null` future.");
168    //noinspection ConstantConditions
169    if (executor == null) throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot wrap future with `null` executor.");
170    return new ReactiveFuture<>(future, executor);
171  }
172
173  /**
174   * Wrap a Google APIs {@link ApiFuture} in a universal {@link ReactiveFuture}, such that it may be used with any
175   * interface requiring a supported async or future value.
176   *
177   * <p>The resulting object is usable as any of {@link ListenableFuture}, {@link Publisher}, or {@link ApiFuture}. See
178   * class docs for more information.</p>
179   *
180   * <p><b>Note:</b> to use a {@link Publisher} as a {@link Future} (or any descendent thereof), the {@link Publisher}
181   * may only emit one value, and no more. Emitting multiple items is considered an error when wrapped in this class and
182   * accessed as a {@link Future}, to prevent silently dropping intermediate values on the floor.</p>
183   *
184   * @see #wrap(Publisher) Wraps a Reactive Java {@link Publisher}.
185   * @see #wrap(ListenableFuture, Executor) Wraps a regular Guava {@link ListenableFuture}.
186   * @param apiFuture API future to wrap.
187   * @param executor Executor to run callbacks with.
188   * @param <R> Return value type for the future.
189   * @return Wrapped reactive future object.
190   * @throws IllegalArgumentException If the passed `apiFuture` is `null`.
191   */
192  public static @Nonnull <R> ReactiveFuture<R> wrap(@Nonnull ApiFuture<R> apiFuture, @Nonnull Executor executor) {
193    //noinspection ConstantConditions
194    if (apiFuture == null) throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot wrap `null` API future.");
195    return wrap(new ApiFutureToListenableFuture<>(apiFuture), executor);
196  }
197
198  /**
199   * Wrap a Google APIs {@link ApiFuture} in a universal {@link ReactiveFuture}, such that it may be used with any
200   * interface requiring a supported async or future value.
201   *
202   * <p><b>Warning:</b> this method uses {@link MoreExecutors#directExecutor()} for callback execution. You should only
203   * do this if the callbacks associated with your future are lightweight and exit quickly. Otherwise, it is heavily
204   * recommended to use the variants of {@code wrap} that accept an {@link Executor}. For instance, the corresponding
205   * method to this one is {@link #wrap(ListenableFuture, Executor)}.</p>
206   *
207   * <p>The resulting object is usable as any of {@link ListenableFuture}, {@link Publisher}, or {@link ApiFuture}. See
208   * class docs for more information.</p>
209   *
210   * <p><b>Note:</b> to use a {@link Publisher} as a {@link Future} (or any descendent thereof), the {@link Publisher}
211   * may only emit one value, and no more. Emitting multiple items is considered an error when wrapped in this class and
212   * accessed as a {@link Future}, to prevent silently dropping intermediate values on the floor.</p>
213   *
214   * @see #wrap(Publisher) Wraps a Reactive Java {@link Publisher}.
215   * @see #wrap(ListenableFuture, Executor) Wraps a regular Guava {@link ListenableFuture}.
216   * @param apiFuture API future to wrap.
217   * @param <R> Return value type for the future.
218   * @return Wrapped reactive future object.
219   * @throws IllegalArgumentException If the passed `apiFuture` is `null`.
220   */
221  public static @Nonnull <R> ReactiveFuture<R> wrap(@Nonnull ApiFuture<R> apiFuture) {
222    return wrap(apiFuture, MoreExecutors.directExecutor());
223  }
224
225  /**
226   * Create an already-resolved future, wrapping the provided value. The future will present as done as soon as it is
227   * returned from this method.
228   *
229   * <p>Under the hood, this is simply a {@link ReactiveFuture} wrapping a call to
230   * {@link Futures#immediateFuture(Object)}.</p>
231   *
232   * @param value Value to wrap in an already-completed future.
233   * @param <R> Return value generic type.
234   * @return Reactive future wrapping a finished value.
235   */
236  public static @Nonnull <R> ReactiveFuture<R> done(@Nonnull R value) {
237    return wrap(Futures.immediateFuture(value));
238  }
239
240  /**
241   * Create an already-failed future, wrapping the provided exception instance. The future will present as one as soon
242   * as it is returned from this method.
243   *
244   * <p>Calling {@link Future#get(long, TimeUnit)} or {@link Future#get()} on a failed future will surface the
245   * associated exception where invocation occurs. Under the hood, this is simply a {@link ReactiveFuture} wrapping a
246   * call to {@link Futures#immediateFailedFuture(Throwable)}.</p>
247   *
248   * @param error Error to wrap in an already-failed future.
249   * @param <R> Return value generic type.
250   * @return Reactive future wrapping a finished value.
251   */
252  public static @Nonnull <R> ReactiveFuture<R> failed(@Nonnull Throwable error) {
253    return wrap(Futures.immediateFailedFuture(error));
254  }
255
256  /**
257   * Create an already-cancelled future. The future will present as both done and cancelled as soon as it is returned
258   * from this method.
259   *
260   * <p>Under the hood, this is simply a {@link ReactiveFuture} wrapping a call to
261   * {@link Futures#immediateCancelledFuture()}.</p>
262   *
263   * @param <R> Return value generic type.
264   * @return Reactive future wrapping a cancelled operation.
265   */
266  public static @Nonnull <R> ReactiveFuture<R> cancelled() {
267    return wrap(Futures.immediateCancelledFuture());
268  }
269
270  // -- Compliance: Publisher -- //
271  /**
272   * Request {@link Publisher} to start streaming data.
273   *
274   * <p>This is a "factory method" and can be called multiple times, each time starting a new {@link Subscription}. Each
275   * {@link Subscription} will work for only a single {@link Subscriber}. A {@link Subscriber} should only subscribe
276   * once to a single {@link Publisher}. If the {@link Publisher} rejects the subscription attempt or otherwise fails it
277   * will signal the error via {@link Subscriber#onError}.</p>
278   *
279   * @param subscriber the {@link Subscriber} that will consume signals from this {@link Publisher}.
280   */
281  @Override
282  public void subscribe(Subscriber<? super R> subscriber) {
283    resolvePublisher().subscribe(subscriber);
284  }
285
286  // -- Compliance: Listenable Future -- //
287  /**
288   * Registers a listener to be {@linkplain Executor#execute(Runnable) run} on the given executor. The listener will run
289   * when the {@code Future}'s computation is {@linkplain Future#isDone() complete} or, if the computation is already
290   * complete, immediately.
291   *
292   * <p>There is no guaranteed ordering of execution of listeners, but any listener added through this method is
293   * guaranteed to be called once the computation is complete.</p>
294   *
295   * <p>Exceptions thrown by a listener will be propagated up to the executor. Any exception thrown during
296   * {@code Executor.execute} (e.g., a {@code RejectedExecutionException} or an exception thrown by
297   * {@linkplain MoreExecutors#directExecutor direct execution}) will be caught and logged.</p>
298   *
299   * <p>Note: For fast, lightweight listeners that would be safe to execute in any thread, consider
300   * {@link MoreExecutors#directExecutor}. Otherwise, avoid it. Heavyweight {@code directExecutor} listeners can cause
301   * problems, and these problems can be difficult to reproduce because they depend on timing. For example:</p>
302   * <ul>
303   *   <li>The listener may be executed by the caller of {@code addListener}. That caller may be a
304   *       UI thread or other latency-sensitive thread. This can harm UI responsiveness.
305   *   <li>The listener may be executed by the thread that completes this {@code Future}. That
306   *       thread may be an internal system thread such as an RPC network thread. Blocking that
307   *       thread may stall progress of the whole system. It may even cause a deadlock.
308   *   <li>The listener may delay other listeners, even listeners that are not themselves {@code
309   *       directExecutor} listeners.
310   * </ul>
311   *
312   * <p>This is the most general listener interface. For common operations performed using listeners, see
313   * {@link Futures}. For a simplified but general listener interface, see
314   * {@link Futures#addCallback addCallback()}.</p>
315   *
316   * <p>Memory consistency effects: Actions in a thread prior to adding a listener <a
317   * href="https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se7/html/jls-17.html#jls-17.4.5"><i>happen-before</i></a> its
318   * execution begins, perhaps in another thread.</p>
319   *
320   * <p>Guava implementations of {@code ListenableFuture} promptly release references to listeners after executing
321   * them.</p>
322   *
323   * @param listener the listener to run when the computation is complete.
324   * @param executor the executor to run the listener in
325   * @throws RejectedExecutionException if we tried to execute the listener immediately but the executor rejecte it.
326   */
327  @Override
328  public void addListener(@Nonnull Runnable listener, @Nonnull Executor executor) throws RejectedExecutionException {
329    resolveFuture().addListener(listener, executor);
330  }
331
332  /**
333   * Attempts to cancel execution of this task.  This attempt will fail if the task has already completed, has already
334   * been cancelled, or could not be cancelled for some other reason. If successful, and this task has not started when
335   * {@code cancel} is called, this task should never run.  If the task has already started, then the
336   * {@code mayInterruptIfRunning} parameter determines whether the thread executing this task should be interrupted in
337   * an attempt to stop the task.
338   *
339   * <p>After this method returns, subsequent calls to {@link #isDone} will always return {@code true}.  Subsequent
340   * calls to {@link #isCancelled} will always return {@code true} if this method returned {@code true}.
341   *
342   * @param mayInterruptIfRunning {@code true} if the thread executing this task should be interrupted; otherwise,
343   *                              in-progress tasks are allowed to complete
344   * @return {@code false} if the task could not be cancelled, typically because it has already completed normally;
345   *         {@code true} otherwise.
346   */
347  @Override
348  public boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning) {
349    return resolveFuture().cancel(mayInterruptIfRunning);
350  }
351
352  /**
353   * Returns {@code true} if this task was cancelled before it completed normally. This defers to the underlying future,
354   * or a wrapped object if using a {@link Publisher}.
355   *
356   * @return {@code true} if this task was cancelled before it completed
357   */
358  @Override
359  public boolean isCancelled() {
360    return resolveFuture().isCancelled();
361  }
362
363  /**
364   * Returns {@code true} if this task completed. This defers to the underlying future, or a wrapped object if using a
365   * Reactive Java {@link Publisher}.
366   *
367   * Completion may be due to normal termination, an exception, or cancellation -- in all of these cases, this method
368   * will return {@code true}.
369   *
370   * @return {@code true} if this task completed.
371   */
372  @Override
373  public boolean isDone() {
374    return resolveFuture().isDone();
375  }
376
377  /**
378   * Waits if necessary for the computation to complete, and then retrieves its result.
379   *
380   * <p>It is generally recommended to use the variant of this method which specifies a timeout - one must handle the
381   * additional {@link TimeoutException}, but on the other hand the computation can never infinitely block if an async
382   * value does not materialize.</p>
383   *
384   * @see #get(long, TimeUnit) For a safer version of this method, which allows specifying a timeout.
385   * @return the computed result.
386   * @throws CancellationException if the computation was cancelled
387   * @throws ExecutionException    if the computation threw an exception
388   * @throws InterruptedException  if the current thread was interrupted while waiting
389   */
390  @Override
391  public R get() throws InterruptedException, ExecutionException {
392    return resolveFuture().get();
393  }
394
395  /**
396   * Waits if necessary for at most the given time for the computation to complete, and then retrieves its result, if
397   * available.
398   *
399   * @param timeout the maximum time to wait
400   * @param unit    the time unit of the timeout argument
401   * @return the computed result
402   * @throws CancellationException if the computation was cancelled
403   * @throws ExecutionException    if the computation threw an exception
404   * @throws InterruptedException  if the current thread was interrupted while waiting
405   * @throws TimeoutException      if the wait timed out
406   */
407  @Override
408  public R get(long timeout, @Nonnull TimeUnit unit) throws InterruptedException, ExecutionException, TimeoutException {
409    return resolveFuture().get(timeout, unit);
410  }
411
412  /**
413   * Structure that adapts a {@link Publisher} to a {@link ListenableFuture} interface. We accomplish this by
414   * immediately subscribing to the publisher with a callback that dispatches a {@link SettableFuture}.
415   *
416   * <p>This object is used in the specific circumstance of wrapping a {@link Publisher}, and then using the wrapped
417   * object as a {@link ListenableFuture} (or any descendent or compliant implementation thereof).</p>
418   *
419   * @param <T> Generic type returned by the future.
420   */
421  @Immutable
422  @ThreadSafe
423  public final static class PublisherListenableFuture<T> implements ListenableFuture<T>, Publisher<T> {
424    /** Whether we have received a value. */
425    private final @Nonnull AtomicBoolean received = new AtomicBoolean(false);
426
427    /** Whether we have completed acquiring a value. */
428    private final @Nonnull AtomicBoolean completed = new AtomicBoolean(false);
429
430    /** Whether we have been cancelled. */
431    private final @Nonnull AtomicBoolean cancelled = new AtomicBoolean(false);
432
433    /** Describes the list of proxied subscribers. */
434    private final @Nonnull Map<String, Subscriber<? super T>> subscribers = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();
435
436    /** Converted/pass-through future value. */
437    private final @Nonnull SettableFuture<T> future;
438
439    /** Subscription, so we can propagate cancellation. */
440    private volatile Subscription subscription;
441
442    /**
443     * Private constructor.
444     *
445     * @param publisher Publisher to wrap.
446     */
447    private PublisherListenableFuture(@Nonnull Publisher<T> publisher) {
448      this.future = SettableFuture.create();
449      publisher.subscribe(new Subscriber<>() {
450        @Override
451        public void onSubscribe(Subscription s) {
452          PublisherListenableFuture.this.subscription = s;
453        }
454
455        @Override
456        public void onNext(T t) {
457          if (received.compareAndSet(false, true)) {
458            PublisherListenableFuture.this.proxyExecute((sub) -> sub.onNext(t));
459            future.set(t);
460            return;
461          }
462          this.onError(new IllegalStateException(
463            "Cannot publish multiple items through `ReactiveFuture`."));
464        }
465
466        @Override
467        public void onError(Throwable t) {
468          if (!completed.get()) {
469            PublisherListenableFuture.this.proxyExecute((sub) -> sub.onError(t));
470            future.setException(t);
471          }
472        }
473
474        @Override
475        public void onComplete() {
476          if (completed.compareAndSet(false, true)) {
477            PublisherListenableFuture.this.proxyExecute(Subscriber::onComplete);
478            PublisherListenableFuture.this.clear();
479          }
480        }
481      });
482    }
483
484    /**
485     * Call something on each proxied publisher subscription, if any.
486     *
487     * @param operation Operation to execute. Called for each subscriber.
488     */
489    private void proxyExecute(@Nonnull Consumer<Subscriber<? super T>> operation) {
490      if (!this.subscribers.isEmpty()) {
491        this.subscribers.values().forEach(operation);
492      }
493    }
494
495    /**
496     * Remove all subscribers and clear references to futures/publishers/listeners.
497     */
498    private void clear() {
499      this.subscribers.clear();
500      this.subscription = null;
501    }
502
503    /**
504     * Drop a subscription (after proxied {@link Subscription#cancel()} is called).
505     *
506     * @param id ID of the subscription to drop.
507     */
508    private void dropSubscription(@Nonnull String id) {
509      this.subscribers.get(id).onComplete();
510      this.subscribers.remove(id);
511    }
512
513    // -- Interface Compliance: Publisher -- //
514
515    @Override
516    public void subscribe(Subscriber<? super T> s) {
517      final String id = String.valueOf(this.subscribers.size());
518      Subscription sub = new Subscription() {
519        @Override
520        public void request(long n) {
521          PublisherListenableFuture.this.subscription.request(n);
522        }
523
524        @Override
525        public void cancel() {
526          // kill self
527          PublisherListenableFuture.this.dropSubscription(id);
528        }
529      };
530      this.subscribers.put(id, s);
531      s.onSubscribe(sub);
532    }
533
534    // -- Interface Compliance: Listenable Future -- //
535
536    @Override
537    public void addListener(@Nonnull Runnable runnable, @Nonnull Executor executor) {
538      this.future.addListener(runnable, executor);
539    }
540
541    @Override
542    public boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning) {
543      boolean cancelled = false;
544      if (!this.completed.get() && this.cancelled.compareAndSet(false, true)) {
545        this.proxyExecute(Subscriber::onComplete);  // dispatch `onComplete` for any subscribers
546        this.subscription.cancel();  // cancel upwards
547        cancelled = this.future.cancel(mayInterruptIfRunning);  // cancel future
548        this.clear();  // clear references
549      }
550      return cancelled;
551    }
552
553    @Override
554    public boolean isCancelled() {
555      return this.cancelled.get();
556    }
557
558    @Override
559    public boolean isDone() {
560      return this.completed.get() || this.cancelled.get();
561    }
562
563    @Override
564    public T get() throws InterruptedException, ExecutionException {
565      return this.future.get();
566    }
567
568    @Override
569    public T get(long timeout, @Nonnull TimeUnit unit)
570        throws InterruptedException, ExecutionException, TimeoutException {
571      return this.future.get(timeout, unit);
572    }
573  }
574
575  /**
576   * Structure that adapts Guava's {@link ListenableFuture} to a Reactive Java {@link Publisher}, which publishes one
577   * item - either the result of the computation, or an error.
578   *
579   * <p>This object is used in the specific circumstance that a {@link ListenableFuture} is wrapped by a
580   * {@link ReactiveFuture}, and then used within the Reactive Java ecosystem as a {@link Publisher}. We simply set a
581   * callback for the future value, upon item-request (one cycle is allowed), and propagate any events received to the
582   * publisher.</p>
583   */
584  public final static class ListenableFuturePublisher<T> implements Publisher<T> {
585    private final @Nonnull ListenableFuture<T> future;
586    private final @Nonnull Executor callbackExecutor;
587
588    /**
589     * Wrap a {@link ListenableFuture}. Private constructor for use by {@link ReactiveFuture} only.
590     *
591     * @param future The future to convert or wait on.
592     * @param callbackExecutor Executor to run the callback on.
593     */
594    private ListenableFuturePublisher(@Nonnull ListenableFuture<T> future,
595                                      @Nonnull Executor callbackExecutor) {
596      this.future = future;
597      this.callbackExecutor = callbackExecutor;
598    }
599
600    @Override
601    public final void subscribe(Subscriber<? super T> subscriber) {
602      Objects.requireNonNull(subscriber, "Subscriber cannot be null");
603      subscriber.onSubscribe(new ListenableFutureSubscription(this.future, subscriber, this.callbackExecutor));
604    }
605
606    /**
607     * Models a Reactive Java {@link Subscription}, which is responsible for propagating events from a
608     * {@link ListenableFuture} to a {@link Subscriber}.
609     *
610     * <p>This object is generally used internally by the {@link ListenableFuturePublisher}, once a {@link Subscriber}
611     * attaches itself to a {@link Publisher} that is actually a wrapped {@link ListenableFuture}. Error (exception)
612     * events and value events are both propagated. Subscribers based on this wrapping will only ever receive a maximum
613     * of <b>one value</b> or <b>one error</b>.</p>
614     */
615    @Immutable
616    @ThreadSafe
617    public final class ListenableFutureSubscription implements Subscription {
618      private final AtomicBoolean completed = new AtomicBoolean(false);
619      private final @Nonnull Subscriber<? super T> subscriber;
620      private final @Nonnull ListenableFuture<T> future; // to allow cancellation
621      private final @Nonnull Executor executor;  // executor to use when dispatching the callback
622
623      /**
624       * Private constructor, meant for use by {@link ListenableFuturePublisher} only.
625       *
626       * @param future Future value to adapt.
627       * @param subscriber The subscriber.
628       * @param executor Executor to run callbacks with.
629       */
630      ListenableFutureSubscription(@Nonnull ListenableFuture<T> future,
631                                   @Nonnull Subscriber<? super T> subscriber,
632                                   @Nonnull Executor executor) {
633        this.future = Objects.requireNonNull(future);
634        this.subscriber = Objects.requireNonNull(subscriber);
635        this.executor = Objects.requireNonNull(executor);
636      }
637
638      /**
639       * Request the specified number of items from the underlying {@link Subscription}. This must <b>always be
640       * <pre>1</pre></b>.
641       *
642       * @param n Number of elements to request to the upstream (must always be <pre>1</pre>).
643       * @throws IllegalArgumentException If any value other than <pre>1</pre> is passed in.
644       */
645      public synchronized void request(long n) {
646        if (n == 1 && !completed.get()) {
647          try {
648            ListenableFuture<T> future = this.future;
649            future.addListener(() -> {
650              T val = null;
651              Throwable err = null;
652              try {
653                val = this.future.get();
654              } catch (Throwable exc) {
655                err = exc;
656              }
657
658              if (completed.compareAndSet(false, true)) {
659                if (err != null) {
660                  subscriber.onError(err);
661                } else {
662                  if (val != null) {
663                    subscriber.onNext(val);
664                  }
665                  subscriber.onComplete();
666                }
667              }
668            }, this.executor);
669          } catch (Throwable e) {
670            subscriber.onError(e);
671          }
672        } else if (n != 1) {
673          IllegalArgumentException ex = new IllegalArgumentException(
674            "Cannot request more or less than 1 item from a ReactiveFuture-wrapped publisher.");
675          subscriber.onError(ex);
676        }
677      }
678
679      /**
680       * Request the publisher to stop sending data and clean up resources.
681       */
682      public synchronized void cancel() {
683        if (completed.compareAndSet(false, true)) {
684          subscriber.onComplete();
685          future.cancel(false);
686        }
687      }
688    }
689  }
690}
